author: azurefa1c0n
content:
I don't think mainnet basefee will ever go that low - if it did, that would signal there is not enough demand for block space. Considering that block space is what Ethereum the blockchain effectively sells, this obviously would mean that the blockchain is not valuable. ETH's primary value accrual is through the burn, which would be zero in this case. Staking rewards would just inflate the supply and dilute the holdings of non-stakers, so everyone would be incentivized to stake - similar to Cardano, for example. What gives ETH the asset value is people choosing to use (and thereby burn a part of) their ETH. So yes, if basefee was 1 gwei, I think that would also mean there is not much value behind ETH.

The reason it wouldn't go that low is because as the basefee gets lower it makes more and more types of transactions valuable. You can see this on Solana and their various p2e games for example which thrive in a lower cost block space environment and the same was true for Axie before it moved to Ronin. Nowadays even before mainnet on-chain games are viable, l2 on-chain games will be. In a few years' time I expect most of mainnet blockspace will be l2 calldata/proofs. Since these are highly valuable (thousands of transactions batched), rollups will be happy to pay 100s of gwei basefee to post them - they will recoup this cost from the l2 fees. This will in turn result in value accrual for ETH and economic security for the mainnet.

author: azurefa1c0n
content: If ETH scales further through Danksharding, this will inflate the block space supply, but I believe it will bring about its own demand cases. Imagine if you could put the contents of Wikipedia or the Library of Congress on-chain. At some point it becomes economically feasible enough to do it and people will proceed to do so. Look at the current throughput of the internet and how much content you can access that wasn't feasible 20 years ago. The demand scaled with the supply and there is no sign of it lagging behind anytime soon.

author: sky.cactus
content:
Things a malicious validator set can do:
1. Censor transactions.  Prevent certain transactions from making it to the blockchain.
2. Reorg back to the most recent finalized block.
3. Cause finality to stop occurring.  This gets more and more expensive as time goes on as they'll be bleeding money executing this attack.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes.  L2s need to be designed such that they are cognizant of the fact that L1 censorship *can* occur for some amount of time.  zkRollups are ideal here, because there usually aren't time constraints.  If an L2 is susceptible to L1 censorship attacks (like optimistic rollups are), then it needs to carefully tune its parameters such that they can withstand a long-ish period of L1 censorship.  They also may want to adjust these up significantly if the L2 has more value on it than L1 has.

author: chris2_2_2
content: Interesting thanks for explaining

author: sky.cactus
content: Assuming the community is healthy and able to coordinate an after-the-fact penalty on censors, then any censorship can be addressed *eventually* through user activated validator penalizing forks.  However, these should be assumed to take weeks to months, and during that time the censorship will continue.  So an OR that has more value on it than Ethereum has in the validator pool should set its parameters such that it can withstand months of censorship before failing.

author: 0x2e
content: don't zkRollups experience the same censorship problem? If they can't get the proof included due to censorship. Ah i guess the argument was to ensure someone has enough time to trigger the dispute for the OR even if the network is heavily censored.

author: sky.cactus
content: With zkRollups, the L2 doesn't finalize until the proof shows up on L1.  With optimistic rollups, the L2 finalizes if some configured amount of time passes without a challenge.  This means that with a ZR, you just end up with finality delayed until the proof lands, and this is visible to everyone.  With an OR, you can still get finality even though the L2 chain isn't valid.
